knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to recite numbers 1 to 30 in the correct order.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Numbers must be counted in the correct order.
● The patterns in counting (for example, ones are repeated each time a new decade or ten is reached as in 21, 22, 23…31, 32, 33…).

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Rote counting of numbers in the correct order to 100 (only verbal counting).
● Rote counting of numbers by tens (beginning at decade numbers as in 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70…).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to recite numbers 1 to 30 in the correct order.
● The sequential aspect of counting (i.e. 1 comes before 2, 2 comes before 3, etc.)

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Numbers must be counted in the correct order.
● The counting sequence is the same, no matter where you begin counting.
● The patterns in counting (for example, ones are repeated each time a new decade or ten is reached as in 21, 22, 23…31, 32, 33…).

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Start rote counting at any number between 1 and 100 and continue to 100 (only verbal counting).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to recite numbers 1 to 30 in the correct order.
● How to recognize, name, and attempt writing numerals 0- 10.
● One to one correspondence.
● The last number said in the counting sequence is the number of objects.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Numbers must be counted in the correct order.
● When counting a set of objects, begin with the number 1.
● A numeral is a symbol for a quantity.
● 0 represents none.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Write a numeral (0-20) to match a set of counted objects.
● Count out a number of objects (0-20) to match a numeral.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to recite numbers 1 to 30 in the correct order.
● How to count a group of 10 arranged objects and 7 scattered objects.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Numbers must be counted in the correct order.
● When counting a set of objects, begin with the number 1.
● One to one correspondence (each object represents a number name).
● Objects are only counted once.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Count a set of objects.
● Keep track of which objects have been counted and which objects have not.
● Point to each object (one at a time) and say the counting sequence.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to recite numbers 1 to 30 in the correct order.
● The sequential aspect of counting (i.e. 1 comes before 2, 2 comes before 3, etc.)
● How to count a group of 10 arranged objects and 7 scattered objects.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Numbers must be counted in the correct order.
● When counting a set of objects, begin with the number 1.
● One to one correspondence (each object represents a number name).
● Objects are only counted once.
● The group of objects is the same quantity, no matter the arrangement.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Count a set of objects.
● Keep track of which objects have been counted and which objects have not.
● Point to each object (one at a time) and say the counting sequence.
● Answer the question, "How many are there?," knowing that the last number counted is the answer.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to recite numbers 1 to 30 in the correct order.
● How to count a group of 10 arranged objects and 7 scattered objects.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Numbers must be counted in the correct order.
● When counting a set of objects, begin with the number 1.
● One to one correspondence (each object represents a number name).
● Objects are only counted once.
● The group of objects is the same quantity no matter the arrangement.
● The number name 15 is larger than the number name 14 and so forth.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Count a set of objects.
● Keep track of which objects have been counted and which objects have not.
● Point to each object (one at a time) and say the counting sequence.
● Answer the question, "How many are there?," knowing that the last number counted is the answer.
● Answer the question, "How many would there be if we added one more object?"

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to recite numbers 1 to 30 in the correct order.
● How to count a group of 10 arranged objects and 7 scattered objects.
● One to one correspondence (each object represents a number name).
● When counting a set of objects, begin with the number 1.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Numbers must be counted in the correct order.
● Objects are only counted once.
● The group of objects is the same quantity, no matter the arrangement.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Count a set of objects (up to 20), and tell how many.
● Given a number, count out that number of objects (up to 20).
● Keep track of which objects have been counted and which objects have not.
● Point to each object (one at a time) and say the counting sequence.
● Answer the question, "How many are there?," knowing that the last number counted is the answer.
● Explain counting strategy.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● The sequential aspect of counting (i.e. 1 comes before 2, 2 comes before 3, etc.)
● Comparative language such as more than, less than, equal to, and different to compare objects.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● The term "greater than" means more than (larger quantity).
● The term "less than" means fewer (smaller quantity).
● The term "equal" means the quantity is the same.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Compare two groups of objects (with up to 10 objects in each group).

● Use matching strategies (e.g., students line up objects with one characteristic [squares] to another row of objects with a different characteristic [circles]. Students can see which objects do not have a partner). Use language greater than, less than, or equal to, after determining the comparison.
● Explain counting strategy.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● The sequential aspect of counting (i.e. 1 comes before 2, 2 comes before 3, etc.)
● Comparative language such as more than, less than, equal to, and different to compare objects.
● Significance of each numeral through multiple experiences with tools, such as ten frames, rekenreks, counters, etc.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● The term "greater than" means more than (a larger quantity).
● The term "less than" means fewer (a smaller quantity).
● The term "equal" means the quantity is the same.
● A numeral is a symbol for a quantity of objects; a representation of a particular quantity.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Compare two numbers (only seeing the numeral) by using the language "greater than, less than, or equal to."

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Rapid recognition of numbers to 5 on their fingers.
● When counting, to say the number names in order.
● Each object represents one number name (one to one correspondence).
● When counting a number of objects, the last number name tells the number of objects counted.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● There are multiple ways to solve addition and subtraction problems.
● How to represent addition and subtraction number sentences.
● The equal sign can mean "makes" or "results in," but always means "is the same number as".
● Addition means to add to or put together, and is noted with a "+" symbol.
● Subtraction means to take from or take apart, and is noted with a "-" symbol.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Act out addition and subtraction situations given by the teacher.
● Model with mathematics by drawing (with no importance to detail of the pictures).
● Picture mental images (dot patterns, pictures of objects, ten frames) of number quantities (also known as subitization).
● Add to, with the result unknown (A + B = ?).
● Take from, with the result unknown (C - B = ?).
● Put together/take apart with total unknown (A + B = ?) and both addends unknown (C = ? + ?).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Rapid recognition of numbers to 10 on their fingers.
● When counting, to say the number names in order, each object represents one number name (one to one correspondence).
● When counting a number of objects, the last number name tells the number of objects counted.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● The equal sign can mean "makes" or "results in", but always means "is the same number as."
● The plus sign (+) means to "put together" or "join."
● A whole can be separated into two or more parts.
● A pair, in this standard, means two numbers.
● How to represent the decomposition of number partners into an equation (e.g., 5 = 2 + 3 and 5 = 4 + 1).

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Break apart a number to find all of its pairs or partners using various objects or tools (e.g., ten-frames, ten wands, rekenreks, dot patterns, double sided counters, etc.).
● Model with mathematics.
● Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
● Record decomposition through drawings or an equation.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Rapid recognition of numbers to 10 on their fingers.
● When counting, say the number names in order.
● Each object represents one number name (one to one correspondence).
● When counting a number of objects, the last number name tells the number of objects counted.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● The equal sign can mean "makes" or "results in," but always means "is the same number as."
● The plus sign (+) means "put together" or "join."
● Two parts (number partners) combine to make a whole (the number 10).
● How to represent the composition of number partners into an equation to represent 10 as the whole (e.g., 5 + ? = 10, 10 = 2 + ?).

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Make 10, when given a number 1-9, using various objects or tools (e.g., ten frames, ten wands, rekenreks, dot patterns, double sided counters).
● Model with mathematics.
● Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
● Record method for making 10 through drawings or an equation.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Rapid recognition of numbers to 5 on their fingers.
● When counting, to say the number names in order.
● Each object represents one number name (one to one correspondence).
● When counting a number of objects, the last number name tells the number of objects counted.
● Addition means to add to or put together (noted by a "+" sign).
● Subtraction means to take from or take apart (noted by a "-" sign).
● The equal sign can mean "makes" or "results in," but always means "is the same number as."

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● To use visual images or representations of numbers (learned through dot patterns) to add or subtract, also known as subitization.
● That numbers can be added in any order (commutative property), and this is a strategy for solving facts, such as 1 + 4 quicker by switching the addends to only have to count up 1.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Quickly add and subtract up to 5.
● Use strategies such as counting on, counting back, fingers, mental representations, etc., to solve problems.

subject: Mathematics
domain: Number and Operations in Base Ten
reporting_category: Number and Operations in Base Ten

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● The counting sequence.
● One to one correspondence.
● How to write and read the numbers 11 to 19.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● The numbers 11 to 19 are created by using a 10 and then adding ones. Numbers can be "put together" (composed) or "broken apart" (decomposed).
● The digit in the tens place describes the number of tens, and the number in the ones place describes the number of ones.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Model with mathematics by using tools such as a ten-frame, drawings, or rekenreks to compose numbers 11 to 19.
● Describe that a ten frame can contain only 10 ones and there will be some leftover when modeling counting numbers 11 to 19.
● Write an addition equation to match the model of tens and ones.
● Count on from 10 (For example, when modeling the number 14 on a ten frame, the student would count "10, 11, 12, 13, 14," instead of beginning with 1.).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Vocabulary such as small, big, short, tall, empty, full, heavy, and light.
● Objects can be measured for different purposes.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● "Length" is the term used to measure how long an object is.
● "Weight" is the term used to measure how heavy an object is.
● An object's weight and length can be described.
● Length and weight are relative to other objects.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Use words to describe an object by stating if it is short, long, heavy, light, etc.
● Know how to determine an object's weight or length using nonstandard units of measurement (balance scale, connecting cubes, paper clips, etc.).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Terms bigger, longer, taller, heavier, same weight, same amount and be able to use them appropriately.
● How to use nonstandard units of measurement.
● Length is the term used to measure how long an object is.
● Weight is the term used to measure how heavy an object is.
● An object's weight and length can be described.
● Length and weight are relative to other objects.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● The terms shorter/taller are used for comparing height.
● The terms heavier/lighter are used for comparing weight.
● When placing objects next to one another, they must be lined up evenly.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Measure objects by placing them next to one another.
● Use words to compare the height of two objects.
● Use words to compare the weight of two objects.
● Model with mathematics by using nonstandard units of measurement (balance scale, connecting cubes, paper clips, etc.).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● How to count objects 1 to 10.
● How to compare and contrast objects by looking at their attributes.
● One to one correspondence.
● The last number said in the counting sequence is the number of objects in the group.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Objects can be sorted by different categories.
● Sorting means to separate objects and put them together with other objects that have something in common (color, shape, etc.).
● A category is a group of similar objects.
● The count is the same when they both have the same number of objects.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Sort objects into categories (e.g., color, size, length, height, weight, area, temperature).
● Count how many objects are in each category (the count will be limited to 10 objects in each category).
● Sort the categories based on their counts (for example, all categories that had a count of 5 objects will be placed together.).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Names of shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).
● Shapes are found in different objects.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● A shape can change location and orientation without changing shape.
● Objects are located in relative positions.
● No matter the position of the object, the object is still the same.
● Objects around us are three-dimensional shapes, and these shapes have a mathematical term (e.g., a ball should be called a sphere).

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Describe everyday objects by telling the name of their shape.
● Describe non-examples of shapes.
● Use terms such as "in front of" to describe the location of an object in relation to another; use prepositions appropriately to describe objects (e.g., the ball is in front of me).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Names of shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).
● Shapes are found in different objects.
● How to describe everyday objects by telling the name of their shapes.
● How to describe non-examples of shapes.
● How to give attributes of each shape.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● A shape can change location, size, color, and orientation without changing shape (non-defining attributes).
● No matter the position of the object, the object is still the same.
● Objects around us are three-dimensional shapes, and these shapes have a mathematical term (e.g., a ball should be called a sphere).

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Name shapes when turned in various directions (e.g., a triangle is a triangle, even when turned upside down).
● Name a shape of various sizes (e.g., the shape is a triangle, even though it is larger than another triangle).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Names of shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).
● Shapes are found in different objects.
● How to describe everyday objects by telling the name of their shapes.
● How to describe non-examples of shapes.
● How to give attributes (defining and non-defining) of each shape.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Objects around us are three-dimensional shapes, and these shapes have a mathematical term (e.g., a ball should be called a sphere).
● Three-dimensional shapes are solid figures composed of two-dimensional shapes (faces) and have volume.
● Two-dimensional shapes are flat.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Determine whether a shape (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres) is two- or three-dimensional.

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Names of shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).
● Shapes are found in different objects.
● How to describe everyday objects by telling the name of their shapes.
● How to describe non-examples of shapes.
● Attributes of each shape.
● How to determine whether a shape is two- or three-dimensional.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● Three-dimensional shapes are solid figures composed of two-dimensional shapes (faces) and have volume.
● Two-dimensional shapes are flat.
● Shapes have different parts that we can describe informally (corners) or formally with math language (vertices).
● Shapes are alike and different.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Compare two shapes (two- or three-dimensional) by describing their similarities (number of sides, vertices, etc.).
● Contrast two shapes (two- and three-dimensional) by describing their differences (number of sides, vertices, etc.).
● Analyze two- and three- dimensional shapes by description of their "parts" (e.g., this shape has no points).

knowledge.label: A student should know
items: ● Name of shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, and hexagons).
● How to compose simple shapes.
● How to use materials, such as Popsicle sticks, play dough, blocks, pipe cleaners, and pattern blocks to create shapes.

understanding.label: A student should understand
items: ● A shape can change location and orientation without changing shape.
● Shapes can be reoriented by using flips, slides, and turns.
● Smaller shapes can be joined to create a new, larger shape.

skills.label: A student should be able to do
items: ● Build larger shapes from using smaller shapes (e.g., pattern blocks).
● Name the new shape that is built from smaller shapes.
